items.abstract: <jats:p>The following Roundtable Is an edited version of the panel discussion that highlighted the Second Century Luncheon, which, on July 11, capped the Centennial Conference at St. Louis, Mo. Introduced by AWWA President Kenneth J. Miller, the panel consisted of Henry J. Graeser, senior consultant, Black & Veatch Consulting Engineers; James V. LaFrankie, president, American Water Works Service Co.; Daniel A. Okun, professor of environmental engineering. University of North Carolina; and Henry J. Ongerth, former chief of sanitary engineering, California Department of Public Health. The panel was questioned by Robert Blanchard of the St. Louis <jats:italic>Globe Democrat</jats:italic>, Martha Shirk of the St. Louis <jats:italic>Post‐Dispatch</jats:italic>, and Mike Owens of radio station KM OX.</jats:p>

title: On labor supply when wants are “Limited”
Investigation in to the Mooring of Supply Vessels by Specialised Bow and Stern Moorings
items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The paper describes investigations presently being carried out at Heriot-Watt University into the dynamic behaviour of supply vessels moored to offshore installations. Physical testing was carried out using 1/100th scale models of supply vessels and specialised moorings in regular waves of varying frequency and height. Irregular waves will be used in future tests and the effect of wind examined in greater detail.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>The paper presents typical results from model tests which include vessel motions in yaw, surge and sway as well as mooring loads in the stern lines and the bow chain. Bow moorings examined are tethered buoys to which the vessel's anchor chain is attached. Two different configurations, as presently being employed in the North Sea, are investigated and compared with results obtained using a catenary bow mooring, provided by the supply vessel's own anchor chain. It is shown that these bow moorings, in conjunction with conventional stern lines alone, are not sufficient to prevent adverse vessel motions at wave frequencies which could be encountered close to natural frequencies of the system. Results are also presented to illustrate the effect of pretensioning the bow mooring. Finally, an investigation was carried out to assess the performance of a position-controlled winch system used in conjunction with the stern moorings. The tests showed that significantly lower line-tensions were obtained in comparison with the conventional stern moorings and snatching was eliminated. Furthermore the motions of the vessel were dramatically reduced.</jats:p>

The Effect of Water Supply on the Growth of lzmir, Palotina and Amarelinho Tobaccos
items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p> The Oriental tobacco variety Izmir has been grown in sand culture in a greenhouse under various degrees of water stress. Plants given 400 cm<jats:sup>3</jats:sup> of water (or nutrient solution) twice a week produced leaves of approximately the same size as field-grown Izmir tobacco, but they were somewhat taller. Plants given 25 cm<jats:sup>3</jats:sup> or less of water twice a week died, and those given more than 400 cm<jats:sup>3</jats:sup> of water twice a week grew larger than field-grown Izmir tobacco. At 49 days after transplanting, the total leaf area per plant was approximately proportional to the amount of water supplied, at least in the range 100-1600 cm<jats:sup>3</jats:sup>. In a second water stress experiment, the growth patterns of the varieties Amarelinho and Palotina, which are not normally grown in conditions of water stress, were found to be different from that of Izmir. Izmir was more tolerant of water stress than the other two varieties, in that complete (but small) plants developed in a shorter time. </jats:p>

title: Pollution Abatement Costs in the Electricity Supply Industry in England and Wales

Wildebeest Connochaetes taurinus (Burchell) and its food supply in Amboseli Basin*
items.abstract: <jats:sec><jats:title>Summary</jats:title><jats:p>Aspects of the wildebeest and its food supply during the dry season are discussed in the light of temporal and spatial distributions. The grazing sequence of wildebeest <jats:italic>Connochaetes taurinus</jats:italic> (Burchell) in the basin during 1973 was monitored on a seasonal basis to determine the response of wildebeest to the changing conditions of available food sources. Data monitored included rainfall, net primary productivity, herbage intake and the physiological response of wildebeest to the available food resources.</jats:p><jats:p>Results suggest that, although grazing in the basin was facilitative, whereby coarse grazers, e.g., elephant <jats:italic>Loxodonta africana</jats:italic> (Blumenbach) moved into the basin before fine grazers, there was a clear‐cut concentration of wildebeest on <jats:italic>Cynodon dactylon</jats:italic> sward and the swamp vegetation in the dry season. This is an indication of the limited area available to the grazing herbivores as the dry season progressed although probably this was preferred pasture at that particular time. Primary productivity data shows that <jats:italic>C. dactylon</jats:italic> is productive throughout the grazing calendar year, a6 compared to other major grasslands in the basin except for the swamp vegetation. Grazing efficiency (G.E.), for example, on <jats:italic>C. dactylon</jats:italic> was 89.9% and that on <jats:italic>Sporobolus marginatus</jats:italic> was 96.3%.</jats:p><jats:p>The physiological response of wildebeest to the changing conditions of available food resources indicate that there is a progressive deterioration of condition by the end of the dry season. High mortality in cattle was enough evidence to suggest the effect of limited food resources available to the grazing herbivores in the Amboseli Basin.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>RÉSUMEÉ</jats:title><jats:p>Des aspects de l'écologie du gnou et de ses ressources alimentaires pendant la saison sèche sont discutés à la lumière des distributions temporelles et spatiales. La séquence d'alimentation du gnou Connochaetes taurinus (Burchell) en 1973 dans le bassin, fut suivie sur base saisonnière pour déterminer les réactions du gnou aux conditions fluctuantes de ses ressources alimentaires. Les résultats suggérent que, bien que le broutage fu&#x030c;t aisé dans le bassin, à cause du fait que les brouteurs et herbe grossière, comme l'éléphant, étaient entrés dans le bassin avant les brouteurs et herbe fine, il y eut une concentration bien nette de gnous sur le gazon à Cynodon dactylon et sur la végétation des marais en saison sèche. Ceci indique la limitation de la surface disponible pour les herbivores au long de la saison sèche bien quéils soient probablement la pa&#x030c;ture préférée à ce moment précis. Les données sur la productivité primaire montrent que Cynodon dactylon est productif tout au long du calendrier de broutage, par rapport aux autres types principaux de savané dans le bassin, sauf la végétation des marais. Le rendement du broutage (G.E.) par exemple, était de 89.90%, sur Cynodon dactylon et de 96.3% sur Sporobolus marginatus. La réponse physiologique du gnou aux conditions variables des ressources alimentaires, indique quéil y a une déterioration progressive de la situation A la fin de la saison sèche. La mortalité du bétail est suffisamment évidente pour suggéser les conséquences de ressources alimentaires limitées sur la herbivores du bassin de l'Amboseli.</jats:p></jats:sec>

title: Differential effect of limitation in oxygen supply on plaquing and multiplication of adenovirus and poliovirus

Regional oxygen consumption and supply in heart: effect of methoxamine-induced pressure rise
container-title: American Journal of Physiology-Heart and Circulatory Physiology
items.abstract: <jats:p> The effect of raising arterial blood pressure 50 mmHg with methoxamine on regional left ventricular O2 supply and consumption was studied in 27 pentobarbital-anesthetized open-chest rabbits. Three groups of animals were studied: 1) control, 2) methoxamine infusion sufficient to raise pressure 50 mmHg, and 3) methoxamine infusion sufficient to raise pressure 50 mmHg with atrial pacing to maintain heart rate. Subepicardial (epi) and subendocardial (endo) O2 saturations were determined with a microspectrophotometric technique. Regional flow was determined with radioactive microspheres and regional O2 consumption by the Fick principle. In the control group, endo venous O2 saturation [31 +/- 3% (SE)] was lower than epi (42 +/- 2%). There were no significant regional differences in blood flow (avg 128 +/- 2 ml . min-1 . 100 g-1). With methoxamine when heart rate fell, there were no differences in regional flow or consumption when compared to control. During methoxamine infusion, when heart rate was maintained, there was higher coronary blood flow (361 +/- 52 ml . min-1 . 100 g-1) and O2 consumption (27 +/- 4 ml O2 . min-1 . 100 g-1). No regional differences, epi vs. endo, were found in this group. After a 50-mmHg pressure rise, the endo region of the left ventricle had an increased O2 consumption mediated by an increased coronary blood flow without a significant rise in O2 extraction, similarly to epi. </jats:p>
